title: Dramatis Personae
filename: 129 - Plague of the Daleks (The Stockbridge Trilogy 3) - Mark Morris_djvu.txt

elements.text: PART ONE
1. INT. CHURCH
(FX: CONTINUING FROM THE END OF ‘THE ETERNAL SUMMER’.
OFF/OUTSIDE — HOWLING WIND, TEMPORARILY OVERLAID BY A ‘TIME
WHIRLPOOL’. NYSSA MATERIALIZES OUT OF THIN AIR, CRASHING INTO A
BOOKCASE FULL OF HYMN BOOKS & SCATTERING THEM ONTO THE STONE
FLOOR. SHE PICKS HERSELF UP & TRIES TO GET HER BEARINGS. SHE
BACKS AWAY SLOWLY, HER VOICE ECHOING SLIGHTLY IN THE EMPTY
CHURCH. )
(COUGHING) Doctor? .. Doctor, where are you? ...
(SOFTLY) Right behind you, Nyssa.
(GASPS) Doctor!
In fact, you’re — ow! — standing on my toe.
(GROANS) What happened to us? I don’t feel at all well.
I’m not surprised. Unshielded temporal transference is not the most comfortable way to travel.
So that’s what we’ve been doing.
With the collapse of the time bubble, we were cast adrift in time. Fortunately, we seem to have anchored ourselves. Come on, deep breaths...
Anchored ourselves? To what?
I don’t know. A particular space-time event, perhaps...
(RECOVERING) Where are we, do you think? It’s so dark.
Well, judging by the acoustics, inside a large, stone-walled building. Hold on, I’ve got some matches somewhere... Ah, here we are.
PLAGUE OF THE DALEKS by Mark Morris 2
FX: A MATCH STRIKING AND FLARING
(STARTLED) Oh!
(CHUCKLES) It’s only Sir Justin, Nyssa. Or rather, his statue.
So we're still in Stockbridge.
FX: FOOTSTEPS ON STONE
(READING THE INSCRIPTION) ‘The journey has not ended here, For his spirit claimed, By death-knell’s chime, Lies Waiting Still-
(FINISHING THE READING AS IF HE KNOWS IT BY HEART) ‘-To cross once more a sea of stars, And sail the tides of time.’
It’s an odd inscription. What do you think it refers to?
The dust of ages. Speaking of which, someone ought to give this place a once-over with a damp cloth.
It is rather grimy, isn’t it? Not to mention freezing cold. I thought churches were supposed to be joyous places. Full of worship and singing.
That’s just on Sundays. And the ambient temperature can be accredited to the fact that it’s winter.
How do you know?
There’s snow at the windows. (MUSING) I wonder which particular shore our ‘tide of time’ has washed us up on.
(TEASING) Don’t Time Lords have an instinct for temporal placement?
Whatever gave you that idea? This particular Time Lord prefers to form his conclusions the old-fashioned way — by assessing the available evidence. Or, better still, by asking someone.
PLAGUE OF THE DALEKS by Mark Morris 3
(FX: ABOVE THE WIND WE HEAR THE GHOSTLY SNATCH OF A CHRISTMAS CAROL, ‘GOD REST YE MERRY GENTLEMEN.’ THE CAROL FADES)
(SHARPLY) What’s that?
Perhaps the neighbourhood spirits took your comment about worship and singing to heart.
(‘HMPHS’) It’s more likely a recording of some sort. But for what reason?
To supplement the congregation? But I doubt we’1ll find the answers here — or the TARDIS for that matter. Come on.
(FX: THEY WALK THE FEW PACES TO THE WOODEN DOOR & OPEN IT. IT
2. EXT. CHURCH GROUNDS/GRAVEYARD

(FX: THE DOCTOR AND NYSSA TAKE A FEW PACES. THEIR FOOTSTEPS MOVE FROM SCRAPING ON THE FLAGSTONES IN THE PORCH TO CRUNCHING ON THE SNOW. THEY STOP. THEY RAISE THEIR VOICES ABOVE THE SWIRLING WIND AND SNOW)
It’s a whiteout!
Ah, ‘Sweet, smiling village, loveliest of the lawn, Thy sports are fled, and all thy charms withdrawn.’

Very nice, Doctor, but this is hardly the time for poetry. Much as I hate to complain, the snow’s blowing into my eyes, and I’m not exactly dressed for blizzard conditions. I know how fond of Stockbridge you are, but the sooner we find the TARDIS and leave, the better, as far as I’m concerned.
Hmm.
(SUSPICIOUSLY) You do think the TARDIS is still here?
Well, I hope so. Let’s head for the High Street and ask around. If nothing else, at least we’ll be assured of a warm welcome in the Green Dragon.
FX: THEIR FOOTSTEPS TRUDGING OFF IN THE SNOW. CUT TO:
PLAGUE OF THE DALEKS by Mark Morris 4
3. INT. GREEN DRAGON INN
(FX: A CRACKLING FIRE; ‘SILENT NIGHT’ PLAYING SOFTLY IN THE BACKGROUND. PUB DOOR OPENS; HOWLING BLIZZARD; PUB DOOR CLOSES )
That’s odd.
There’s no one here.
(CALLS) Hello? Anyone about?
Doctor, look: half-finished drinks... an uncompleted game of some sort...
Dominoes. And look — coats on the backs of chairs; a walking stick propped against a table. This doesn’t bode well, Nyssa.
You don’t think that as the Time Vortex spat us out, these people were... dragged in?
It’s a worrying possibility.
Perhaps the singing we heard in the church was a time echo?
(FX: THE DOOR BEHIND THE BAR SUDDENLY OPENS & FLAPS SHUT, LIKE A TWO-WAY KITCHEN DOOR, AS MRS WITHERS APPEARS. NYSSA GASPS)
(LOUD AND ALMOST PAINFULLY JOLLY) Good evening. Awful weather, rsp t: ate
Oh! But I...
Are you all right, dear? You look as white as —
Cheese?
Beg your pardon, dear?
PLAGUE OF THE DALEKS by Mark Morris
As white as cheese. It’s a simile.
Yes, dear, I’m sure. Awful weather, isn’t it?
Er, yes. Where is everybody?
Everybody?
Your customers?
Oh, they must have popped out. Quick perambulation round the —
The?
Awful weather, isn’t it? What can I get you?
Ginger beer for me. Nyssa?
Just water, thank you.
(FX: LIGHT BEEPING AS MRS WITHERS ENTERS THE ORDER INTO THE TOUCH-PAD TILL ON THE BAR)
Right you are, m’dears. And how about something to eat? I have some lovely hot pot.
Thank you, yes. Very warming on such a cold night. (BEAT, AS MRS WITHERS ENTERS THE HOT POT ORDER INTO THE TILL) Excuse me, do you mind if I ask a question?
Ask away, dear.
You are Mrs Marjorie Withers, aren’t you?
Indeed I am, dear. For my sins.
PLAGUE OF THE DALEKS by Mark Morris 6
Mrs Withers, what year is this?
(FX: SILENCE, APART FROM B/G CRACKLING FIRE; CHRISTMAS CAROLS; WIND AND SNOW OUTSIDE)
Mrs Withers?
Awful weather, isn’t it? I’ll get you that hotpot.
FX: SHE BUSTLES AWAY THROUGH THE TWO-WAY DOOR
What’s wrong with her, Doctor?
Selective memory loss, caused by a recent trauma? Some kind of mental conditioning? How old would you say she is, Nyssa?
I don’t know. Sixty perhaps.
Hmm. When I last stayed here — in 1982, if memory serves — Mrs Withers was in her seventies. Which ought to make this the mid- 1960s.
My knowledge of Earth technology isn’t perfect, Doctor, but... isn’t that unlikely?
Not unlikely — impossible. That’s a touch screen till behind the bar. And the dartboard has an electronic score sheet. If not for Mrs Withers, I’d say this was the early twenty-first century.
So what does all this mean, Doctor?
I’m not sure. Yet.
(FX: MRS WITHERS REAPPEARS THROUGH THE TWO-WAY DOOR & APPROACHES THE TABLE NEAREST THEM)
Here we are, m’dears! Settle yourselves down by the fire.
PLAGUE OF THE DALEKS by Mark Morris T
(FX: THEY DO SO, PULLING THE CHAIRS OUT & SITTING DOWN. CLATTERING OF CROCKERY AND GLASSWARE AS MRS WITHERS SETS THEIR
Thank you, Mrs Withers. It all looks most... um... appetising.
There’s plenty more if you’re hungry. Awful weather, isn’t it?
Mm.
(FX: MRS WITHERS MOVES AWAY, HUMMING ALONG TO THE CHRISTMAS CAROLS ON THE RADIO. ONCE AGAIN THE TWO-WAY DOOR FLAPS AS SHE EXITS)
(LOW VOICE) Doctor, this food’s rotten. And the bread’s covered in mould.
FX: THE DOCTOR PICKS UP HIS GLASS TO EXAMINE THE CONTENTS
(RUEFULLY) Even my ginger beer’s flat. (PUTS DOWN HIS GLASS & ROUSES HIMSELF) Time to pay up and be on our way.
(FX: THE DOCTOR STANDS UP ACCOMPANIED BY THE SCRAPING OF HIS CHAIR ON THE FLOOR. HE GETS SOME MONEY OUT OF HIS POCKET — A COLLECTION OF NOTES & COINS — AND PLACES THEM ON THE TABLE)
Come along, Nyssa. I think we need to cast our net a little further afield.
(STANDING UP, TOO, WITH CHAIR SCRAPING) Go outside again, you mean?
Well, unless you’d rather stay for dessert?
No, thank you.
(FX: THEY OPEN THE PUB DOOR AGAIN & EXIT, SHUTTING THE DOOR
PLAGUE OF THE DALEKS by Mark Morris 8
4. EXT. THE STREETS OF STOCKBRIDGE
FX: A HOWLING BLIZZARD. FOOTSTEPS CRUNCHING THROUGH SNOW
(SHOUTING) I hope fifty pounds was enough.
(ALSO SHOUTING) More than, I should imagine. So what are we looking for now, Doctor? The TARDIS, or an explanation for what’s happening here?
Well... either would be welcome. The important thing is to keep an open mind.
I think I’d find it easier to do that if I’d had the opportunity to dress for these conditions.
Mind over matter, Nyssa. Think warm thoughts.
Thank you, Doctor. That’s so helpful.
(FX: THROUGH THE BLIZZARD COMES THE APPROACHING SOUND OF A HORSE-DRAWN CARRIAGE, RATTLING OVER COBBLES. THE CLACK OF HOOVES BEARS DOWN UPON THEM)
(ALARMED) Doctor!
I hear it, Nyssa.
Where is it? I can’t see anything!
More sound effects, that’s all. The snow’s so thick that a carriage would barely make a sound in these conditions.
(FX: THE DIN OF THE CARRIAGE REACHES A CRESCENDO... THEN FADES, LEAVING A GHOSTLY ECHO)
Are you all right, Nyssa?
A little shaky. Though I’ve yet to decide whether that’s due to cold or fear.
PLAGUE OF THE DALEKS by Mark Morris 9
FX: ABOVE THE BLIZZARD, WE HEAR THE RAUCOUS CAWING OF CROWS.
Yet more sound effects?
Not this time. Look above us, Nyssa. On the roofs and telephone
wires.
(GASPS) There’s hundreds of them!
Carrion crows. Said to be harbingers of doom.
FX: A SINGLE CROW, CAWING LOUDLY, SWOOPS DOWN
Look out, Doctor!
FX: THE CROW SWOOPS BY; THE DOCTOR DUCKS; IT’S A NEAR MISS
(SHAKEN) That was rather too close for comfort. Its wing-tip brushed my face.
Why would it attack you like that?
I’m not sure. Crows are scavengers by nature and, although they do sometimes supplement their diet with live flesh, they don’t generally prey on anything much larger than field mice.
That one was obviously an exception.
Not so much of one, I fear. Look, Nyssa.
FX: THE CAWING OF CROWS GROWS LOUDER, MORE THREATENING
What are they doing?
Massing for attack. (SUDDENLY URGENT) Here they come!
FX: CROWS SWOOP DOWN, AMID A CACOPHONY OF RAUCOUS CRIES
Run, Nyssa!
PLAGUE OF THE DALEKS by Mark Morris 10
Where?
Let’s try... this cottage!
(FX: B/G HOWLING WIND AND SCREECHING CROWS; F/G THE RAPID UNLATCHING OF A GATE; THUD OF FEET THROUGH SNOW)
Quickly, Doctor! (SHE SQUEALS AND FLAILS AT ATTACKING BIRDS)
(FX: SOUND OF METAL IMPLEMENT FRANTICALLY PROBING AT LOCK; A CLICK; THE DOOR OPENS WITH A CREAK)
In here!
(FX: A CACOPHONY OF FLUTTERING FEATHERS, CAWING & NYSSA’S
PLAGUE OF THE DALEKS by Mark Morris 11
5. INT. COTTAGE
(FX: THEY RUN INSIDE. THE DOOR SLAMS, MUFFLING THE OUTSIDE FX. THE CROWS’ FLUTTERING & CAWING DIES AWAY DURING THE SCENE)
(GASPING) You’re quite the housebreaker, Doctor.
Little trick I picked up from the Great Omani. (BEAT) Now, I wonder what made the crows behave like that?
Perhaps they were just hungry? Unable to find food?
No, it wasn’t that. They didn’t attack us, for one thing.
(ASTONISHED) Didn’t attack! What do you think-
(QUIETLY, DECISIVELY) How many times did they peck you, Nyssa?
Well... none. But only because I fought them off.
You think so? Their reactions are quicker than yours. And their beaks are razor-sharp. If they’d wanted to draw blood, they would certainly have done so.
So what were they doing?
Not sure. Assessing us? Warning us? Deliberately impeding our progress?
Are they really that intelligent?
Not ordinarily. Interesting, isn’t it?
So what do we do now?
Consider our options. Let’s try through here.
FX: HOLLOW SOUND OF FOOTSTEPS ON WOODEN FLOORS
PLAGUE OF THE DALEKS by Mark Morris 12
This place is completely empty.
And has been for some time, judging by the dust. (BEAT) I’m guessing this leads to the kitchen.
FX: CREAK OF DOOR OPENING. DISTANT SPRING BIRDSONG.
Oh, goodness!
Fascinating! (QUIETLY) ‘When the hounds of spring are on winter’s traces...’
Are we really looking out on to a spring day, Doctor? It’s not an illusion?
If it is, it’s a convincing one. I’m more inclined to believe this anomaly is temporal rather than psychological.
Do you think it’s safe to go outside?
I don’t see why not. Just keep an eye out for those crows.
FX: NYSSA RUNS TO BACK DOOR, OPENS IT. CUT TO:
PLAGUE OF THE DALEKS by Mark Morris 13
6. EXT. SUNLIT BACK GARDEN
(FX: THE HOWLING BLIZZARD HAS NOW BEEN REPLACED BY THE TRILL OF BIRDSONG)
Look, Doctor. You can still see patches of melting snow here and there.
An instant thaw, followed by an artificially-induced spring. Impressive technology.
Technology? You don’t think this could be a natural phenomenon then? A freak result of climate change, for instance?
Five minutes ago those trees were bare. Now they’re laden with blossom. And look there, Nyssa. Bluebells.
Is that significant?
It means this is April or May. And whilst spring snowfalls are not uncommon, there’s still a definite nip in the air. It would need to be considerably hotter than this to affect such a rapid thaw.
So what is going on here, Doctor?
(FX: A DISTANT CRY OF ‘HOWSAT?’— TAKEN UP BY A SMALL BUT VOCIFEROUS CROWD)

(OBVIOUS DELIGHT) Well, a cricket match, for one thing. A little early in the year, perhaps, but a surer sign of civilisation would be impossible to find. Come along, Nyssa. The village green is... this way.
FX: FOOTSTEPS HEADING OFF. FADE TO:
PLAGUE OF THE DALEKS by Mark Morris 14
7. EXT. VILLAGE GREEN
(FX: THE CLICK OF LEATHER ON WILLOW; MUTTERS AND SHOUTS FROM PLAYERS AND SPECTATORS. THE DOCTOR & NYSSA ARRIVE & STOP.)
Here we are. Look, Nyssa, there’s even a tea tent. I’11 treat you to a macaroon.
Don’t become too complacent, Doctor. Your harbingers of doom are still overhead.
(DISTRACTED) Hmm?
Those awful crows. Dozens of them.
FX: DISTANT CRIES OF CROWS
Oh, don’t mind them. They seem to have lost interest in us for the time being.
FX: CRACK OF BAT ON BALL
(SHOUTING) Good shot! Well hit!
(EXASPERATED) Doctor.
(DISTRACTED) Hmm?
Shouldn’t we be asking about the TARDIS?
(SIGHS) You’re quite right. I’1ll make a few discreet enquiries, starting with this fellow. (CLEARS HIS THROAT) Excuse me?
BEAT
(QUIETLY) Perhaps he’s deaf, Doctor. He is rather an old gentlemen.
(RAISING HIS VOICE) Excuse me, I don’t suppose you happen to have seen a tall blue box around here?
PLAGUE OF THE DALEKS by Mark Morris 15
BEAT
Blue box? About so high? Says ‘Police’ above the door?
BEAT
I don’t think he understands me, Nyssa. He’s looking at me rather strangely.
(NERVOUSLY) Something’s happening, Doctor.
What?
The cricketers. They’ve stopped their game and they’re heading towards us.
(CALLS CHEERILY) Hello there! Please, carry on. Don’t mind us.
They’re all coming this way. I don’t like this, Doctor.
(MUTTERS) Get ready to retreat, Nyssa. Back the way we came.
(FX: FAINT, THEN RAPIDLY RISING SOUND OF A DESCENDING SPACE CRAFT)
Doctor, what’s that?
(SHOUTING ABOVE THE INCREASING ENGINE NOISE) It’s a passenger shuttle. A space craft.
(ALSO SHOUTING) Alien?
No. Look at the insignia. It’s from Earth.
A woman from the 1960s. Weather-altering technology. Spaceships. What’s happening here, Doctor?
I’m beginning to wonder. I’1ll ask one of the cricketers.
PLAGUE OF THE DALEKS by Mark Morris 16
You don’t think they’re hostile?
There’s no indication of it. They’re ignoring us. (BEAT) Excuse
me. (BEAT) I say, excuse me.
(SPEAKS SLOWLY, AS THOUGH HE’S NOT ALL THERE) What?
Would you mind telling me — who’s in the shuttle?
Visitors.
And what visitors might those be?
Visitors. Come every day. ‘Cept Monday.
I see. And where do the visitors come from?
Outside.
Doctor, the shuttle’s powering down. It’s landing on the village green.
FX: SHUTTLE POWERS DOWN
And here are the welcoming committee.
FX: THE HUM OF A SKIMMER
That’s not a twenty-first century vehicle either, is it?
No, it’s a skimmer. Developed around the fortieth.
FX: THE SKIMMER COMES TO A HALT. DOORS HISS OPEN
Come on, Nyssa. Let’s introduce ourselves.
Is that wise, Doctor?
PLAGUE OF THE DALEKS by Mark Morris 17
We won’t know until we do it, will we?
FX: THE DOCTOR & NYSSA ADVANCE, & WE GO WITH THEM
OFF, BUT GETTING LOUDER AS THE DOCTOR APPROACHES; GLUMLY
Three visitors! I remember when we used to get eight full shuttles a day.
That’s the Trust’s fault, Dad. If they didn’t keep cutting our budget, we’d still be pulling in the punters.
(GRUNTS) Aye, but that doesn’t alter the fact that they’1ll still blame us. They’re just looking for an excuse to close us down.
(CALLING) Good morning! Or is it afternoon? Time just seems to fly here.
(ASTONISHED) Who in Creation are you?
I’m the Doctor and this is my friend, Nyssa.
That’s as may be, but.. who are you?
We're visitors. (BEAT) Like the people in the shuttle?
Visitors? But that’s impossible. How did you get here?
I’m afraid that’s a little hard to explain.

You need a level one security code to gain access to the Bubble. (SUDDEN REALISATION) Oh, hang on, I’ve rumbled you. You’re Trust Inspectors, aren’t you? You’ve been sent to make a.. what do they call it? An assessment of our profitability.
Is it really that obvious?
PLAGUE OF THE DALEKS by Mark Morris 18
(SIGHS) I’ve been dreading this day. Knew it was bound to come sooner or later, of course. But tell me upfront, no mucking about — are you here to close us down?
Not necessarily.
Maybe we ought to introduce ourselves before we start peppering you with questions. I’m Lysette Barclay and this is my dad, Isaac. (BEAT) But you probably know that already?
We know a great deal less than you might think, Miss Barclay. We've been... um, thrown in at the deep end, you might say.
We arrived in a blizzard.

Ah. The winter quarter. Back in the old days we had snowball fights, a Christmas service in the church, mulled wine in the pub. Now the visitors tend to leave in the autumn quarter and the rest of us just stay indoors, batten down the hatches.
We went to the pub. It did look as though everyone had left in rather a hurry.
Stage dressing. We leave the pub like that for the summer lunchtime session. It saves time.
FX: THUMPING FROM INSIDE THE SHUTTLE; FISTS ON METAL
(MUFFLED; ANGRY) You out there! Are you going to keep us in this tin can all day?
Excuse us. Duty calls.
Of course. Pretend we aren’t here. We’1ll just..observe.
(FX: CHEEP AND BEEP OF KEYPAD-TYPE BUTTONS; LOCKS DISENGAGING; A DOOR HUMMING OPEN. LYSETTE & BARCLAY AD LIB AS THEY OPEN THE DOOR. WHILE ALL THIS IS GOING ON...)
PLAGUE OF THE DALEKS by Mark Morris 19
(LOW VOICE) What did Mr Barclay mean about getting access to ‘the Bubble’, Doctor?
LV) Environment bubble. I assume we’re inside one. (MUSING
Which must put us somewhere beyond the Critical Age.
(LV) Critical Age?

(LV) By the forty-fifth century, solar flare activity was so extreme that over 95% of the Earth’s surface had become uninhabitable. Not that it really mattered. Humankind had been colonising other planets for centuries by then. Hardly anyone lived on the home world any more.
(LV) So this is what? The last outpost of civilisation?
(LV) Something like that.
(EXPANSIVELY) Madam! Gentlemen! Welcome to Stockbridge! I trust you had a pleasant flight?
(WARBLING, HIGH-PITCHED ALIEN VOICE) Merely adequate.
I’ve never endured such a tortuous — or torturous — experience. My poor back feels as though it’s been forced through a fusion grinder.
Oh. Well, I’m very sorry (to)-
Plus the aircon howled like a banshee, and the food was
appalling.
(TENTATIVELY) It wasn’t that bad, dear.
Some of us, Vincent, expect basic catering standards for our hard-earned credits. My linguine tasted like the floor scrapings of a containment dome.
PLAGUE OF THE DALEKS by Mark Morris 20
(WEAKLY) My fish was very nice.
And as for dessert...
I, too, found the in-flight sustenance to be lacking in the correct nutrient levels required to sustain comfort...
FX: AD LIB MUTTERING IN B/G AS NYSSA TALKS IN F/G TO DOCTOR
(F/G BUT LV) Who’s the purple gentleman with the tentacles, Doctor?
(LV) He’s a Lucerian. Very scholarly race. Blunt and humourless, but essentially non-aggressive.

(CLEARS HIS THROAT) Madam, gentlemen, I’m very sorry for the... er, less than ideal start to your day. My name is Isaac Barclay, and I’m the co-ordinator here at the Stockbridge Heritage Experience. As you know, Stockbridge is one of only three such remaining sites in the entire Northern Hemisphere. Here, we can offer you the long-lost delights of a real English village, beautifully preserved. But before I blather on for too long, I’ll hand you over to my daughter, Lysette, who’1ll be showing you round and answering your questions today. I hope you have a wonderful time and come to love Stockbridge as much as we do. Thank you.
(APPLAUDS — THEN REALISES HE IS THE ONLY ONE) Oh... er... mmm.
Hello everyone. Before we start, I need to confirm a few particulars. According to my data pad, this party should consist of Professor Rinxo Jabbery of the Lucerian Unity...
(A BURBLE OF ASSENT) Present!
And Mr and Mrs Vincent Linfoot of New Cheadle, Satellite 94.
Present. Obviously.
Excellent. If I could just scan your ID chips...
ora)
PLAGUE OF THE DALEKS by Mark Morris 21
(B/G GENERAL AD LIB CHAT. F/G BARCLAY CHATS TO THE DOCTOR & NYSSA)
(EMBARRASSED) Attendances are a little down, I’m afraid.
Evidently history isn’t what it used to be.
Can I be blunt, Doctor?
By all means.

The truth is..we work our socks off here. But we just don’t get the support and funding from your lot that we need and — frankly — deserve. Look around you, Doctor. Not only is this a valuable historical resource, it’s a beautiful place. There’s nowhere like Stockbridge in the entire universe, and it would be an absolute, unparalleled tragedy if we were to lose it.
I quite agree.
(SURPRISED) Do you?
Oh yes. And believe me, Mr Barclay, if there’s anything we can do to help keep Stockbridge up and running, we’1ll do it. Won’t we, Nyssa?
Er.. yes. Absolutely.
(TAKEN ABACK) Well, that’s... very gratifying to hear, Doctor.
So tell me, Mr Barclay-
Isaac. Call me Isaac.
Even better. Tell me, Isaac, how many of you run this place?
PLAGUE OF THE DALEKS by Mark Morris 22
Well, to be honest with you, that’s one of the reasons why we're falling to rack and ruin. Since the cutbacks, there’ve only been the three of us — myself, Lysette and our tech, Dobson.
Don’t the villagers help?
(LAUGHS) Oh, very droll! I like that: ‘the villagers’!
(BEWILDERED) Well, don’t they?
(SUDDENLY REALIZING SHE’S SERIOUS) Blimey, they really did throw you in at the deep end, didn’t they? Didn’t they give you data packs?
I’m afraid not.

(SIGHS) The villagers are nth generation clones. Most of ‘em can barely function as human beings any more. You see, the more we dip into the same gene pool the more it degrades. Life spans get shorter with each generation...
And does that apply to the animal life too? The crows, for example?
The crows?
Yes, we were attacked by a flock of crows earlier.
Attacked? Really? Well, that shouldn’t happen. The birds and animals are all ALs.
What are ALs?

Now I know you’re teasing me! Artificial life-forms, as you very well know. I’1ll have to get Dobson to look at the inhibitor grid — if he’s not too busy. Problem is, soon as one thing gets fixed, another goes on the blink.
PLAGUE OF THE DALEKS by Mark Morris 23
Have any of your problems here involved time, Mr Ba- Isaac?
How do you mean, ‘time’?

Well, it’s just that when we arrived we heard... sounds. Part of a Christmas carol. A carriage rattling over cobbles. We wondered whether it was caused by some sort of time distortion. The past invading the present.
(LAUGHS) You talking about ghosts, miss?
Well... not exactly.
CONTINUES TO LAUGH
(TERSELY) It was rather an unsettling experience.
(CONTROLLING HIMSELF) Yes... I’m sure it was. Forgive me. It’s just.. there’s a simple explanation for what you heard.
I’d very much like to hear it.

We have a sound archive in Stockbridge. Lysette uses the recordings to give her guided tours a bit of oomph. Unfortunately, like everything else round here, the audio system’s on the blink. Random sounds leak through at odd intervals. It’s just something else to add to Dobson’s ever- expanding list.
There you are, Nyssa. Sounds effects, as we thought.
Hmm.

(COMING ACROSS) Right, Dad, we’re ready to move out. (LOW VOICE) That Mrs Linfoot’s going to be a bundle of laughs. She complains about everything. Don’t suppose you’d like to come along, would you, Nyssa? See the set-up? I could do with the moral support.
PLAGUE OF THE DALEKS by Mark Morris 24
Well, LI...
Yes, why don’t you, Nyssa? You could keep an eye out for... anything interesting.
(SIGHS) All right. What are you going to do?
I’d rather like to see the environment system — if Isaac doesn’t mind showing me?
No, Doctor. My pleasure.
Right then, we’ll leave you to it. See you later.
Cheerio, love. Oh, and, er... (LOWERS VOICE) don’t take any nonsense from the old bat.
(LAUGHS) I won’t. You ready, Nyssa?
Yes. Doctor; Mr Barclay.
See you later, Miss.
Yes. Have fun.

(OFF; MOVING AWAY) Right then, madam, gentlemen. Our first stop will be the church, the spire of which you can see poking above the rooftops over there. As we head towards it, I’1ll draw your attention to points of interest, starting with the village green to your left. The green is regarded as the focal point of the community, and has been the site of many significant events over the years. (FX: FOOTSTEPS ECHO HOLLOWLY, SUGGESTING THEY HAVE ENTERED A CATHEDRAL-LIKE SPACE. THEY WALK SLOWLY INSIDE.)

(HORRIFIED SURPRISE) Look out! Daleks!

I thought so. Look at these readings.
Sorry, it’s all gobbledegook to me. What am I looking at?
Well, assuming that these six columns relate to the cryo- chambers here... it appears that three of the Daleks were revived and three perished.
That one looks as though it exploded. What’s all that icky green stuff?
The remains of the Dalek creature inside the casing.
Nice. What do you think killed the other two?
Qn
PLAGUE OF THE DALEKS by Mark Morris 93

If I’m reading this data correctly, they’ve been here for over seventeen centuries. Simple mechanical failure, perhaps? That might account for the deaths. It’s a credit to Dalek technology that three of the cryo-units have remained functional for so long.
Six Daleks minus three dead Daleks equals three active Daleks. Yes? Well, that’s not so bad, is it?
Don’t let their lack of numbers lull you into a false sense of security. One Dalek would be more than capable of wiping out Stockbridge and everyone living here.
(DEFLATED) Well that’s it then. There’s nothing we can do.
We can arm ourselves — with knowledge. The Doctor often says that information is the best weapon. (FX: NYSSA PUSHES SOME MORE BUTTONS ON THE COMPUTER DISPLAY) Information like...
FX: A SCHEMATIC POPS UP
What is it? A schematic of the Dalek base?
Yes, but look at the amount of damage caused by geological movement. The metal shell is riven with cracks and stresses.
You mean it could collapse at any moment?
Well, certainly within another couple of centuries.
(LAUGHS BLEAKLY) I’m not sure we can wait that long.
No. But perhaps we could give nature a helping hand.
(EXCITED) You think we could? How?
According to this, the Daleks have created an electronic master link from this base to the main environment manipulator, which controls your weather.
Q2
PLAGUE OF THE DALEKS by Mark Morris 94
The manipulator? But that’s where the Doctor was!
Exactly. He must have had the same idea: control the environment and you control Stockbridge. Except I doubt he knows anything about this master link. He was probably trying to stop the rain.
Good for him. But what are we going to use the environment manipulator for?
Seismology. If we could access to the seismological controls we could create an earthquake severe enough to tear this place apart.
Sounds like a plan. So where is this master link?
That’s the problem. According to the schematic here, it’s in the main control room — where the Daleks are.
So, let’s draw the Daleks out.
Good idea. But how?
FX: A DISTANT CHIME SOUNDS
What’s that? Have they found us?
I don’t think so. According to the schematic both Daleks are still in the main control room. Wait a minute: there are three there now.
What’s that red blob with them? A fourth Dalek?
(WITH DREAD) No. A Time Lord.
